speaker: [Plays "Nieta" by Harold Land, from Harold In The Land Of Jazz, Contemporary Records (1958). Personnel: Rolf Ericson: trumpet; Harold Land: tenor saxophone; Frank Butler: drums.]
words: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RjudDKOZxYU

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Okay.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Oh all set?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Just to be safe.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: That sounded quite a bit more like Clifford, like Max Roach and Clifford Brown and... That's a good record. I don't especially want to hear it again, but I enjoyed it while it was going. Give it three stars.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Did any individuals stood out, anything? Tenor? Rhythm section, tune, anything else?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: It was all very competent. Nobody stuck out especially. It's like it had a very good group sound.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Okay. Any particular preference coast wise? What would you say?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Well, it certainly sounds New York-ish.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: [Plays "Improvisation" by Buddy Collette, from Buddy Collette's Swingin Shepherds, EmArcy Records (1958). Personnel: Buddy Collette: flute; Paul Horn: piccolo; Bud Shank: alto flute; Harry Klee: bass flute.]
words: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vjftMjBP2Fg&t=991s

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: That was wild.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah (laughs).

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: I liked the writing very much if it was written, and if it wasn't written I like it even more.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah. Was it hard to tell?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Yeah. At first, it sounded as if it must've been written and towards the end more and more it seemed too random to be written. Which could be very good writing or very good playing or luck. No, eliminate luck. With more than two people it takes more than that.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: But I liked it very much. I would imagine it would have to be on the East coast somehow because I think there's more flute players out here. There seem to be an awful lot of them on their record. Is it one of those Herbie Mann organizations?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Was it possible to guess at the instrumentation? Or was that too hard to tell?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Well the only thing I could hear was an alto flute and a collection of flutes and a piccolo and some kind of hand-played drum.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah that's about it. Well as long as you liked it that's the main thing. What would you rate it out of five?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Three, three and a half.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, okay.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Wilder was doing it, if you want to know the truth. It sounds like those Monday night studio musicians, woodwinds workshop groups, which are great to play in, but I don't think people should have to listen.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah that's right. Well you wouldn't recognize anybody.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: No. I'd say, well, it's hard to... Well about the three stars academically for the musicianship involved in playing it that well.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: But no star for the idea of doing it. Not as a jazz record anyway.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Five stars. Don't give any five unless you think it's sensational.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Well, I think it's a good idea.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: What's a good idea?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Wait, no, actually I better clarify that. I've heard Dizzy play Begin the Beguine. I think with some kind of a rhythm, but that certainly wasn't it. I don't think unless I'm losing my mind.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: You're...

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: And I enjoyed that, but I don't enjoy this. It was much too overwritten and ornate and oppressive. I... I don't know if it was the musicians' fault, they all seemed to play pretty well. But I don't like the arrangement or again, the idea of doing that particular thing.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Seems to get harder to find records that you just like to listen to.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: You mean as opposed to having to study them all or what?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Having to react to them, I suppose.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well, yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: I- I started out sort of being conservative with the amount of stars in the theory that eventually I would reach something that I would want to give five stars to, but it seems to be working the other way. And I was never very good at fractions. I don't know. I guess two stars.

speaker: [Plays "Margo" by Teddy Charles, from New Directions 4, Prestige Records (1954). Personell: Teddy Charles: vibes, piano, composer; Shorty Rogers: trumpet; Jimmy Giuffre: tenor saxophone; Shelly Manne: drums; Curtis Counce: bass.]
Paul Desmond
words: Curiouser and curiouser. I have no idea who they were, but I enjoyed listening to it very much. I would like to listen to it many times again. It had that air of improvisation about it again, which puzzles me because I don't think that could have all been improvised, but it certainly had the feel.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Because if it was, it was certainly by very harmonically sophisticated guys.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Sure.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: It was beautiful, very moody and reflective. Four...

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Four stars?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Four and a half stars. I don't know what I'm saving that half a star for.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well, maybe the real thing will come along. Any coast, ideas on that?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Well it certainly doesn't fit in with the stereotype of either coast and I imagine the individuals could be from both coasts. It's much more of an individual thing than anything else.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: We have to wonder whether your selection of records represents journalistic foxiness or musical taste. Well, again I don't know who it was. Maybe Marge Hyams or somebody like that. I didn't like it very much. It... Oh. Playing accordion is sort of a self inflicted occupational hazard that requires an awful lot in the way of content to justify it. Which in this case didn't happen. I had, sort of had that, oh, 50% better than Muzak feeling. I'd say two stars.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Well that was Andre and Shelly. One of those show tune albums. I love that rhythm section.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: And Andre seems to be getting closer and closer to his goals of sounding like Horace Silver.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, he sure does.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Three and a half stars.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: It's a wonderful sound to hear again. That's got to be Gerry and Chet. Unless, well in this kind of a test, I should never say things like that because if there exists an expert duplication, I'm sure you'd be playing it for me. But I still think that's Gerry and Chet. It certainly isn't the best thing they've done, but it has a nostalgic value. If there is anything to be said about West coast or East coast jazz. If you're classified Gerry Mulligan's group as West coast, which is kind of silly because it just happens to be where they were at when they met.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah that's always...

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: I would say this is one of the most valid things to come out of the West coast.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: And they've done a number of remarkable things. Four stars. Oh, maybe I'm being nostalgic.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: It sounded good. I liked to hear it.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Like the rhythm section?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: I was... It was okay. It wasn't too demanding a situation for a rhythm section. So it's hard to tell.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: [Plays "Red Pepper Blues" by Art Pepper, from Meets The Rhythm Section, Contemporary Records (1957). Personnel: Paul Chambers: bass; Philly Joe Jones: drums; Red Garland: piano.]
words: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gG-2pGIH54A

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: This reminds me of that blindfold test that Bill Russo took where he heard a Lee Konitz record, said it sounded as if he had fallen back into the mainstream. Which killed me at the time because it seems awful to think that you would change your playing after careful consideration and have somebody else interpret it as an unfortunate accident.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: And my first thought was if it's Lee, he's drowning. Somebody should save him. I shouldn't say all these things. Can I edit this later?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: No.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: That's not fair. And I guess it was probably Bud Shank and I sympathize with him because I have the same problem in my occupation, which is to... It's a problem of one who was sort of raised in the atmosphere of cool jazz, trying to sound hostile enough to be currently acceptable.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Why am I saying all this? It was well done, but it wasn't really too moving.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: How about the piano?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Piano sounded a little more authentic, but it's easier to do that on piano. You don't have the problem of sound.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: It's easier to shift.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: True.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: And there never was... Well piano has pretty much sounded the same throughout all this, more so than horns. There's an aura of kind of competent funkiness about this. But it seems superficial and not as if it's really meant somehow.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Any comment on the bass solo?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: I honestly didn't hear it.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: It was an arco solo.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Oh.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well I guess-

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Could you, could you play it again, and I'll be happy to-

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: If you want me to. No, it wasn't that important. I can if you like.

Paul Desmond
words: Philly Joe Jones.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

words: Are we still going?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: Sounds like like Paul Chambers and Philly Joe Jones, which I suppose would mean that the alto player was Art Pepper. But the situation remains pretty much the same.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Did you rate it?

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: No, I didn't. Let's see if Tom James was two stars... Hard to... I sympathize with you.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well two is fair and three is good.

speaker: Paul Desmond
words: I'd say three and a half for just a very good but uninspired job.
